prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

head.headtext: Distinguishing Knowledge and Skills from Confidential Information

para.paratext: Canadian case law has consistently made a distinction between an employee's knowledge and skill and the employer's confidential information. While the general concept is clear, in practice, it is often very difficult to distinguish between the two. The leading decision which attempted to define the distinction is the English case of Printers & Finishers Ltd. v. Holloway:[1]

If the information in question can fairly be regarded as a separate part of the employee's stock of knowledge which a man of ordinary honesty and intelligence would recognise to be the property of his old employer and not his own to do as he likes with, then the court, if it thinks that there is a danger of the information being used or disclosed by the ex-employee to the detriment of the old employer, will do what it can to prevent that result by granting an injunction. …..

[In this case] such knowledge is not readily separable from [the employee's] general knowledge of the flock printing process and his acquired skill in manipulating a flock printing plant, and I do not think that any man of average intelligence and honesty would think that there was anything improper in his putting his memory of particular features of his late employer's plant at the disposal of his new employer.

The Canadian courts have acknowledged and made use of this distinction to determine what information can be used by former employees in their new employment. In Genesta Manufacturing Ltd. v. Babey,[2] the court discussed the distinction and concluded that the general skills learned by employees during the course of their employment are the employees' own property and can be used following the conclusion of the employment relationship. Genesta also provided the underlying rationale behind the doctrine, which was to prevent the “granting [of] a monopoly to the employer”.

Often a distinction is made between “objective” and “subjective” information. Generally, the courts have been prepared to protect objective or “unique” information that relates to a company's products or processes. Information that is “known generally” in an industry, relates to the company's organizational structure, or is the personal knowledge of the employee, is considered to be “subjective” in nature.[3] Such information is frequently referred to as an employee's “know-how”. Know-how will normally include information taken away in the employee's head, particularly where such information relates to the skills used by the employee in his or her day-to-day activities. On the other hand, the employer's documents, photographs, drawings, etc. will more likely be considered to be information of an “objective” nature.

The courts have generally applied the standard of a reasonable employee, based on the leading case of Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd.,[4] when seeking to determine whether an employee should have been aware that information was confidential.[5] Faccenda Chicken[6] also supported this view by emphasizing the “obvious character” of the information in the circumstances of the employment relationship. Where the employee should have realized that information was to be maintained in confidence, there will be an implied obligation on the employee to do so.

Generally, all employees are required to use information in a manner consistent with the circumstances under which the employer provided it. The nature of employment in general (i.e., trust-based) and the facts of the individual relationship set the parameters in which information may be used.[7] Even fiduciary employees are generally free to take the knowledge and skills they gain during the course of employment and use them to establish a competing business.[8] Since the employer normally imparts information to the employee for a specific job-related purpose, the permitted use of the information may often be defined in part by reference to the employee's duties.[9]
Printers & Finishers Ltd. v. Holloway, [1965] 1 W.L.R. 1 (Ch.), at pp. 5-6.
Genesta Manufacturing Ltd. v. Babey (1984), 48 O.R. (2d) 94, 29 B.L.R. 36 (H.C.J.).

See, for example, Herbert Morris Ltd. v. Saxelby, [1916] 1 A.C. 688 (H.L.); Morison v. Moat (1851), 9 Hare. 241, 68 E.R. 492 (Ch.); Triplex Safety Glass Co. v. Scorah, [1937] 4 All E.R. 693 (Ch.); United Indigo Chemical Co. v. Robinson (1931), 49 R.P.C. 178 (Ch.).
Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd., [1969] R.P.C. 41 (Ch.).

See, for example, Ken Graham Consumer Products Ltd. v. Sunbeam Corp. (Canada) Ltd. (1989), 25 C.P.R. (3d) 52 (Ont. H.C.J.), at pp. 76-7; Eaton Fund Distributors Ltd. v. Poulin (1973), 12 C.P.R. (2d) 35 (Ont. H.C.J.); United Indigo Chemical Co. v. Robinson (1931), 49 R.P.C. 178 (Ch.).

Faccenda Chicken Ltd. v. Fowler, [1986] 1 All E.R. 617 (C.A.). Many other cases have supported this test. See, for example, Eaton Fund Distributors Ltd. v. Poulin (1973), 12 C.P.R. (2d) 35 (Ont. H.C.J.); and R.L. Crain Ltd. v. Ashton, [1950] 1 D.L.R. 601, [1950] O.R. 62 (C.A.), where it was held that the employee should have recognized that the information was something to be preserved solely for the benefit of the employer.
Boehmer Box L.P. v. Ellis Packaging Ltd., 2007 C.L.L.C. 210-025 (Ont. S.C.J.).
See for example, Pizza Pizza Ltd. v. Gillespie (1990), 75 O.R. (2d) 225, 45 C.P.C. (2d) 168, 33 C.P.R. (3d) 515 (Gen. Div.).
See, for example, Cercast Inc. v. Shellcast Foundries Inc. (1972), 8 C.P.R. (2d) 254 (F.C.T.D.).
